title: 104_s638
content: There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 is amended to limit payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands for fiscal years 1996 and beyond to amounts specified in the Agreement of the Special Representatives on Future Federal Financial Assistance. Payments to the Northern Mariana Islands shall be limited to amounts specified in the Agreement of the Special Representatives on Future Federal Financial Assistance, subject to all requirements of the Agreement. Additional amounts may be provided in any fiscal year as needed until Congress decides otherwise. The Agreement specifies payments to the Northern Mariana Islands, with additional amounts available as needed until Congress decides otherwise. For fiscal year 1996, funds are allocated for infrastructure projects in American Samoa, while for fiscal years 1997 and beyond, the funds are designated for projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and the Republic of. For fiscal years 1997 and beyond, funds are available solely for capital infrastructure projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Republic of Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million is allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas, with a maximum of $3 million per year thereafter as provided in Appropriation Acts. In fiscal year 1997 and beyond, up to $3 million annually may be allocated for infrastructure projects in the Northern Mariana Islands to address immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues, including detention and corrections needs. The specific projects will be outlined in a five-year infrastructure assistance plan. In fiscal year 1997 and beyond, up to $3 million annually may be allocated for infrastructure projects in the Northern Mariana Islands to address immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues, including detention and corrections needs. The specific projects will be outlined in a five-year plan developed by the Secretary of the Interior in consultation with the island governments and updated annually. The Secretary of the Interior will develop a five-year plan for capital infrastructure needs, prioritizing projects and considering master plans, Corps of Engineers' recommendations, maintenance set-asides, and local cost-share requirements. The Secretary of the Interior will develop a five-year plan for capital infrastructure needs, prioritizing projects based on recommendations from engineers. An incremental set-aside of up to $2 million per year may be proposed for maintenance and emergencies. The Secretary of the Interior may allocate funds for infrastructure projects, with additional contributions for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll from any Federal source, not exceeding $10 million for an emergency fund. The Secretary of the Interior may allocate funds for infrastructure projects, with additional contributions for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll not exceeding $32 million from any Federal source after January 1, 1995. Contributions are contingent upon a full settlement agreement and proper auditing. Contributions for resettlement activities on Rongelap Atoll are a final settlement of US obligations, with funds to be audited and used solely for resettlement. Federal agencies in the Marshall Islands can provide assistance through the Secretary of the Interior. This does not limit ex gratia assistance under section 105(c)(2). The Marshall Islands can provide funds for resettlement on Rongelap through the Secretary of the Interior. Ex gratia assistance under section 105(c)(2) of the Compact of Free Association Act of 1985 is not limited, but assistance for individuals not resettling on Rongelap is contingent on full funding for resettlement being provided. SEC. 2. FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE. Effective thirty days after enactment, minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, with rates starting at $2.75 per hour and increasing to $3.05 per hour in 1996. The minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will start at $2.75 per hour, increasing to $3.05 per hour in 1996. Subsequent increases will occur annually by thirty cents per hour or to match the rate set by the Fair Labor Standards Act. Once it reaches the FLSA rate, the minimum wage will align with that standard. The minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will start at $2.75 per hour, increasing to $3.05 per hour in 1996. Subsequent increases will occur annually by thirty cents per hour or to match the rate set by the Fair Labor Standards Act. Once it reaches the FLSA rate, the minimum wage will align with that standard. The text chunk "SEC. 3. REPORT." is a section heading that likely pertains to a report mentioned in the previous paragraph about the minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with other government officials, must report to Congress by March 15 each fiscal year on funds allocated for immigration, labor, or law enforcement activities in the CNMI. The report includes immigration data, such as the number of non-US citizen contract workers in the CNMI. The Immigration and Naturalization Service provides immigration information on non-US citizen contract workers in the CNMI, including their treatment and conditions, and any foreign government interference with their rights under US law. The Immigration and Naturalization Service is investigating the treatment of non-US citizen contract workers, foreign government interference with workers' rights, laws in the Northern Mariana Islands affecting Federal interests, detention facility adequacy, the accuracy of the alien identification system, and reasons for Federal agencies' limitations. The investigation by the Immigration and Naturalization Service includes examining the accuracy and reliability of the computerized alien identification system and its compatibility with the agency's system. Additionally, it aims to understand why Federal agencies are unable to fully enforce laws in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands without funding from the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will work together to identify and potentially exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks to the Commonwealth or the United States. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF LOCAL EMPLOYMENT IN THE MARIANAS. Section 8103(i) of title 46 of the United States Code is amended to allow aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels within the US waters surrounding the CNMI. Fish processing or fish tender vessels operated exclusively from a port within the CNMI and US waters are deemed to be employed in the United States under 46 U.S.C. 8704. This amendment allows aliens in the CNMI to work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels within US waters surrounding the CNMI. The amendment allows aliens in the CNMI to work as unlicensed seamen on certain vessels within US waters surrounding the CNMI, with specific changes made to sections of the United States Code. SEC. 6. CLARIFICATION OF OWNERSHIP OF SUBMERGED LANDS IN THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS. Public Law 93-435 (88 Stat. 1210) is amended by including the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in various sections previously mentioning Guam and the Virgin Islands. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands is included in various sections of Public Law 93-435, replacing references to Guam and the Virgin Islands. The date of enactment for the Northern Mariana Islands is specified in the amended law. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual "State of the Islands" report to Congress on various territories, including economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, and financial management capabilities. Section 501 of Public Law 95-134 is amended to replace "the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands" with "the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia." This amendment was passed by the Senate on July 20, 1995.
